transcript.text: You’re now familiar with Cartesian product and relations, let us now see some problems
on it.
Consider this set A one two three and B to be a, b, c and d.
The question is what is A cross B. It’s a very straightforward question.
A cross B will have the elements, I am going to take one element from A and B and I am
going to follow this procedure for all the elements of A and B. So what will A cross
B look like?
A cross B looks like set of all x comma y where x belongs to A and y belongs to B. So
A cross B will be 1 comma a, 1 comma b, 1 comma c, 1 comma d, 2 comma a, 2 comma b,
2 comma c, 2 comma d, 3 comma a, 3 comma b, 3 comma c and 3 comma d.
So all these are the elements of A cross B. Please note A cross B is not equal to B cross
A.
You see here 1 comma a belongs to A cross B, but a comma 1 does not belong to A cross
B. I am just making a point here that A cross B and B cross A are not same in general.
So what is going to be the cardinality of A cross B?
So to find the cardinality of A cross B, we use the formula it is equal to cardinality
of A into cardinality of B. Cardinality of A happens to be 3 and B happens to be 4, and
hence cardinality of A cross B is equal to 12.
The next question: Consider the set S having the elements 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.
Now I am going to define the relation R on the set S as set of all (a, b) such that a
+ b is less than equal to 4.
So what are the elements in this relation R. So the relation R has elements, which satisfied
this condition a +b is less than or equal to 4.
Now, so it will precisely have 1 comma 1, 1 comma 2, 1 comma 3, 2 comma 1, 2 comma 2
and 3 comma 1.
Please note 1 comma 3 and 3 comma 1 are not the same, as illustrated in the first question,
and hence, they are to be returned as two different elements.
So that is it.
These are the elements in the relation R.
